item.title: Best Springtrap Build in Dead by Daylight: FNAF Perks and Add-Ons
item.description:
Springtrap is the headlining killer of Dead by Daylight 's Five Nights at Freddy's Chapter, and he's one of the coolest characters the game has seen to date. Springtrap's kit gives him incredible mobility and map control, and you can really mess with Dead by Daylight survivors while they're trying to repair generators and secure their escape.

Springtrap's abilities are strong enough on their own, but you can make him even stronger with perks and add-ons that enhance his powers even further. Some of Springtrap's best add-ons are low rarity, so you won't have to spend too many Bloodpoints in the Bloodweb. He makes great use of some other killer's perks, too, so veteran Dead by Daylight players should have plenty of tools in their arsenal for The Animatronic.

Best Dead by Daylight Springtrap Build

These are the best perks and add-ons to use with Springtrap in Dead by Daylight .

  • Add-On: Help Wanted Ad
  • Add-On: Streamers
  • Perk: Phantom Fear
  • Perk: Distressing
  • Perk: Sloppy Butcher
  • Perk: Surveillance (The Pig)

Outside of his ridiculously strong rare add-ons (which let him throw his axe across the map through security doors or grant his axe a gigantic Terror Radius of its own), Springtrap's more common add-ons are still quite transformative for his basic gameplay loop.

The Help Wanted Ad add-on shows the trajectory of axe throws so you don't have to worry about aiming, and this is exceptionally helpful for chases where you don't have time to line things up. The Streamers add-on just makes Springtrap travel through security doors 20% faster, but since you'll spend a lot of time teleporting across the map with these doors, every second counts.

Phantom Fear is one of The Animatronic's unique perks, and it causes survivors to scream and have their auras revealed when they look at Springtrap while inside his Terror Radius. Combined with the Distressing perk — which increases Springtrap's Terror Radius by 20% — you'll constantly hear screams and mark survivors despite Phantom Fear's lengthy 60-second cooldown.

Since Springtrap is such an aggressive killer, Sloppy Butcher i s a great fit for him as well. It's a Dead by Daylight mainstay, causing basic attacks to inflict Hemorrhage and Mangled . It makes it much harder for survivors to heal, and since you'll be landing axe trick shots all the time because of the Help Wanted add-on's aim assist, it's an especially oppressive perk for The Animatronic. Survivors will leave behind more prominent blood trails, too, so you can track them down more easily.

Finally, the Surveillance perk (unlocked with The Pig killer from the Saw Chapter) is a great fit for Springtrap because of his exceptional mobility. This perk highlights regressing generators damaged by Springtrap with a white aura. When the regression is interrupted and a survivor begins repairs, that generator's aura will turn yellow. Since Springtrap can use security doors to teleport around the map, you can surprise a survivor working on a generator within seconds.

Dead by Daylight players will surely adapt to Springtrap's abilities as time goes on, but the core tenants of his playstyle become so much stronger with these perks and add-ons. This build transforms Springtrap into a ridiculously annoying killer that reveals survivors regularly and locks down generators in different corners of the map. You'll be able to zoom through security doors and embed your axe within survivors if they escape your melee range, and your perks will make it super easy to track them down for the killing blow or reposition with the help of a security door.

item.title: World of Warcraft Patch 11.1.7 is Missing a Few Things
item.description:
World of Warcraft Patch 11.1.7, Legacy of Arathor, is officially out, but there seem to be a couple of things missing: Geya’rah doesn’t have any voice acting, and there was no Twitch Drop to celebrate the update. While both have likely explanations for their absences, it is no less notable that this otherwise exciting World of Warcraft update is missing a few staples.

Patch 11.1.7, Legacy of Arathor, is officially live in World of Warcraft . This update marks the last one of The War Within Season 2 and introduces tons of exciting features, including Lorewalking, Overcharged Delves, and a new story campaign chapter called Rise of the Red Dawn.

However, there are a couple of things missing from this update that players have noticed along the way. Geya’rah – Mag’har leader and daughter of Durotan and Draka from the alternative timeline of Warlords of Draenor – plays a major role in the Rise of the Red Dawn campaign in WoW Patch 11.1.7, acting as one of the major Horde representatives in the story. That said, as discovered by Wowhead contributor Portergauge, the character seems to be unvoiced in the English version of the live game, despite counterparts Faerin Lothar, Danath Trollbane, and Eitrigg all having spoken dialogue. Additionally, no Twitch Drops were given away to celebrate the update.

Missing Voice Lines and Twitch Drops in WoW Patch 11.1.7

The missing voice lines could technically be caused by a glitch, but it is more likely that they were a result of the SAG-AFTRA video game acting strikes, which just recently reached a suspension. Geya'rah's voice actor, Laila Berzins, is known for her roles as Xiao from Genshin Impact, Persephone and Demeter from Hades , and Emberthal, also in World of Warcraft . At press time, Berzins has not made any comments about the missing role on social media, but it could be that the missing voice lines were because Blizzard was respecting the picket line.

As for the Twitch Drops, it is likely just a matter of Blizzard not having prepared anything for the update. WoW Twitch Drops began with the release of Dragonflight – version 10.0 – in November 2022 and have since been available for every single update for nearly three years. While not a guarantee, fans have grown accustomed to these gifts, so their absence is keenly felt.

Geya’rah’s missing voice lines aren’t the first ones in recent World of Warcraft history. Renzik “The Shiv” from Patch 11.1 was also unvoiced, despite having a major role in the campaign. Joe Ochman, a known SAG-AFTRA member, is credited for Renzik’s voice acting, which further corroborates the strike as the most likely reason for the missing voice lines. It remains to be seen if Blizzard intends to record this missing dialogue in the future, but now that the strike is ending, hopefully, gamers will see it added in a later update.

item.title: FNAF: Secret of the Mimic - All Audio Log Locations
item.description:
There's more to uncover at Murray's Costume Manor in FNAF: Secret of the Mimic than meets the eye, and it's not just the crazed animatronics lurking around every corner. There are various types of collectible items to find, many of which can lead to achievement rewards and the unlocking of special endings for the story.

One type of collectible item you should set out to find in FNAF: Secret of the Mimic are the audio logs left by Erwin and Fiona. There are numerous ones to find throughout the facility, and some can be rather challenging. If you find yourself stuck, here's where to find them all.

The following guide contains heavy spoilers regarding unlockable areas, characters, and all endings for FNAF: Secret of the Mimic. Please read ahead with caution.

What Are Audio Logs in FNAF: Secret of the Mimic?

Audio Logs are a certain type of collectible in FNAF: Secret of the Mimic (not to be confused with the Gift Box Collectibles or Text Logs) that are found via special tape cassette players scattered throughout the game. To "unlock" them, you simply need to press the "Play" button on the cassette player, and the audio log in question will play.

They provide pieces of supplemental lore related to Edwin Murray, Fiona, and their son David that help thread the story together more cohesively. So, if you're especially interested in the game's story details, it's all the more incentive to collect these audio logs. You can also play them as often as you want.

Finding and listening to all Audio Logs in the game also gets you the Good Listener trophy/achievement.

All Audio Log Locations in FNAF: Secret of the Mimic

There are a total of 22 Audio Logs to find in FNAF: Secret of the Mimic , and while some are easy enough to find via following the main story, others require more thorough exploration and completion of optional objectives and collectible items.

Audio Log 1 - Employee Office Near Big Top Showroom

This audio log is found in an employee office directly to the right when you first enter the atrium that leads to the Big Top Showroom. You need 'Repair' level clearance to get into the room. Go inside and up the stairs, and the cassette player will be on the wall immediately to your left.

Audio Log 2 - Office Above Storytime Showroom

Getting to this audio log requires finding and accessing the secret Storytime Playroom area. Start by accessing the door behind the Smack a Clown carnival game (knock out all teeth but one to get to it), then work your way through the obstacles ahead to eventually access the showroom.

Make your way to the narrow path behind the stage and crawl to the elevator lift in the corner. This takes you up to the office overlooking the Storytime Showroom, and the cassette player is found inside to your right. You also unlock the 'Goodnight, Sleep Tight' trophy/achievement for reaching this area.

Audio Log 3 - Second Floor of Area Before Roof Access

This audio log is found in the two-floor safe area before you head outside through the Roof Access door. There's also a Clearance Upgrade Machine and an Inventory Box here. You can find the cassette player up on the second floor on the right side wall.

Audio Log 4 - Stage Control Room Above Theater

To get this audio log, head into the Theater via the main atrium and look for the hidden passage along the right side wall behind a pile of clutter. This will lead to an open vent you can crawl through that leads to a hallway where the Stage Control Room is. Head inside, and the cassette player will be sitting on the counter.

Audio Log 5 - Assembly Office Inside Workshop

This audio log is found inside the Workshop area, just in the office next to the assembly platform where you put together the Springlock suit. The cassette player is sitting on the couch across from the HELPER computer.

Audio Log 6 - Office Near Entrance to Backstage Area

When you first enter the Backstage section in the Springlock suit, there will be a small office ahead of you to the right. The cassette player containing an audio log is on a table inside, just next to the HELPER computer.

Audio Log 7 - Entrance to Loading Bay

You can find this audio log when you enter the Loading Bay area, where you'll see the next crane puzzle to move around several animatronic platforms. The cassette player is on the wall straight ahead, near an Inventory Box and a whiteboard depicting the progress of Edwin's many projects.

Audio Log 8 - Storage Room Above Loading Bay

After you make your way across the crane puzzle in the Loading Bay and go up the stairs to the top, this audio log can be found inside a sparse storage room directly to the right. You need Admin access to enter it, though you should have it for the story by this point. The Admin Wing itself is just beyond, so make sure to grab this before then.

Audio Log 9 - Upper Floor of Warehouse

Before heading to the Admin Wing, you can and should also go grab this audio log, as it's easily accessible from the same area above the Loading Bay. Look for the double doors labeled 'Warehouse,' and they'll lead you to the upper catwalk overlooking the Warehouse you were evading Chica in earlier. Go all the way around the catwalk and through the security door ahead (Admin clearance required), and the cassette player will be on the wall at the far end of the room.

Audio Log 10 - Break Room in Admin Wing (First Floor)

This audio log is found on the first floor of the Admin Wing area, where Chica is patrolling in a minefield of Cupcake animatronics. The Break Room is accessible from the left side of the maze-like room, so navigate your way over and get through the security door (Admin clearance). The cassette player will be sitting on the kitchen counter in the corner, just by the HELPER computer.

Audio Log 11 - Edwin Murray's Office

This audio log is found inside Edwin Murray's office, which is in the Admin Wing on the second floor. You can only access it after you upgrade your Data Diver with Executive clearance (also on the second floor). The cassette player is sitting on the low bookshelf behind Edwin's desk under the window.

Audio Log 12 - Elevator Room Before Basement Level

After you escape Chica in Edwin's Office by going through the vent shaft from the security monitor room, you'll wind up in a room with an elevator that forcibly leads you down on a detour to the Basement level. Before you get in, though, this cassette player is sitting on a knocked-over server tower near the elevator itself.

Audio Log 13 - Basement Level

After you take the elevator down to the Basement level (after the events in Admin Wing/Edwin's Office), head into the open room. Here, you'll find this cassette player on the wall on the left side, near an Inventory Box and HELPER computer.

Make sure to unlock this immediately before heading down into the sub-basement. An animatronic boss awaits you there, and you won't be able to backtrack from that point.

Audio Log 14 - Secret Room Inside Basement

This audio log is probably the most dangerous one to get to, as it's deep in the basement maze where you face off with the White Tiger animatronic.

Audio Log 15 - Returns Room in Main Hallway

This audio log is found inside the Returns room at the far end of the Main Hallway of the facility. Go past the Warehouse main entrance, and the door to the Returns room will be around the corner on your right. You need Admin level clearance to enter this room, so you will need to revisit this area after getting said clearance. Upon entering, the cassette player will be on the wall on the left side.

Audio Log 16 - Storage Room on Second Floor of Main House (Glitched Clearance Required)

To get this audio log, you must first unlock the secret ending by gathering all Giftbox Collectibles, completing the Moon.EXE mini-game , and receiving Glitched Clearance for the Data Diver .

In the Main House (or Erwin's House), head up the stairs to the second floor and go to the door immediately on the right. You need Glitched clearance to enter it. Go inside, and the cassette player will be on a table on the left side.

Audio Log 17 - Blueprint Room on Second Floor of Main House (Glitched Clearance Required)

To get this audio log, you must first unlock the secret ending by gathering all Giftbox Collectibles , completing the Moon.EXE mini-game , and receiving Glitched Clearance for the Data Diver .

While on the second floor of the Main House, go left and hack into the first door on the left. You need Glitched clearance to enter it. Go inside where you find walls covered in animatronic blueprints. The cassette player will be on a table on the right side.

Audio Log 18 - Prototype Freddy Fazbear Pizzeria (Alternate Ending Required)

To access this Audio Log, you must engage the alternate ending of the story by running the Parachute.EXE program and making your way to the depths of the facility where a mock-up of Freddy Fazbear's Pizza is found full of early prototypes of familiar animatronics.

After you select the 'Turn On Stage Lights' option on the HELPER computer in the center of the pizzeria room, a room to the right of the stage will open. Along with the Freddy Fazbear suit for you to wear, there's an Executive-tier security door. Open it, and the cassette player will be hanging on the wall inside.

Audio Log 19 - Bathroom Next to Prototype Freddy Fazbear Pizzeria (Alternate Ending Required)

To access this Audio Log, you must engage the alternate ending of the story by running the Parachute.EXE program and making your way to the depths of the facility where a mock-up of Freddy Fazbear's Pizza is found full of early prototypes of familiar animatronics. After escaping out of the main pizzeria room to the bathroom area, you'll find this cassette player hanging on a wall.

Audio Log 20 - Passage to Main House from Prototype Freddy Fazbear Pizzeria (Alternate Ending Required)

To access this Audio Log, you must engage the alternate ending of the story by running the Parachute.EXE program and making your way to the depths of the facility where a mock-up of Freddy Fazbear's Pizza is found full of early prototypes of familiar animatronics.

After escaping out of the main pizzeria room and meeting F10-N4, she'll send you to the main house. On the way to the train cart that takes you there, this cassette player will be sitting on a table next to the tracks.

Audio Log 21 - Desk on First Floor in Main House (Alternate Ending Required)

To access this Audio Log, you must engage the alternate ending of the story by running the Parachute.EXE program and make your way into the depths of the facility. This Audio Log is sitting on a desk in the room directly to the left from where you enter the Main House that F10-N4 sends you to. Be careful of the Mimic actively patrolling the area.

Audio Log 22 - Destroyed Attic in Main House (Alternate Ending Required)

To access this Audio Log, you must engage the alternate ending of the story by running the Parachute.EXE program and make your way into the depths of the facility. This audio log is up in the attic area of the Main House that's partially destroyed, just after you get past the door on the second floor via the keypad code obtained from the Film Reels in the house (the code is randomized).

The cassette player is on the wall near the table with the HELPER computer (where you activate Cradle.EXE). This is the final audio log found in this particular ending.

item.title: Fallout 76 Breaking One Big Promise is All I Want for Christmas
item.description:
Beware spoilers for Amazon Prime Video's Fallout series.

While I’m happy for The Elder Scrolls fans who were treated to Oblivion Remastered earlier this year, surely I’m not alone in thinking that the Fallout franchise could also benefit from a new release right now, considering that the most recent mainline Fallout game is Fallout 76 , which will be turning seven years old this year. Realistically, the most likely options for a ‘new’ Fallout game in 2025, ahead of Fallout 5 ’s distant release, would be a remake or remaster.

However, there’s a fourth alternative that Bethesda could and should explore, since it could fill this void in the Fallout franchise, all the same. It would mean breaking a big promise made by Fallout 76 ’s developers, but it would arguably be the perfect Christmas present for Fallout fans like me if the next big Fallout 76 update coming at the end of this year explores a direct tie-in with the upcoming season two of the Fallout show that’s set to release around the same time, which both have the convenient opportunity to pay Fallout: New Vegas ’ iconic wasteland a visit.

Why Fallout 76 Should Break Its Promise Regarding the Fallout Show

Born in 1999, I grew up watching my older brother and cousins play Fallout 3 and Fallout: New Vegas , so I consider myself a ‘ Fallout: New Vegas baby.’ By the time I was old enough to pick up my first RPG and seriously commit to it, it had to be Fallout: New Vegas . Naturally, I’m still madly in love with the modern Fallout games, and despite Fallout 76 ’s troubled launch, this has been my favorite game ever since I started playing it in 2021.

Fallout: New Vegas Deserves More Than a Cameo in 2025

I’m also a huge fan of the Fallout show, but the dozen-or-so hours I’ll spend watching season two of the Fallout show when it comes out this December are nothing compared to the hundreds of hours I could easily spend playing the games. So, while I’m stoked that season two of the Fallout show will be visiting the setting of Fallout: New Vegas , this shouldn’t be the only homage that Fallout: New Vegas gets this year, especially in place of a proper sequel.

Not long after the first season of the Fallout show debuted, Fallout 76 ’s creative director, Jon Rush, made a broad promise at Quakecon 2024 that Fallout 76 isn’t going to directly tie into the Fallout show. Given the golden opportunity Fallout 76 has to collaborate with both the Fallout show’s upcoming second season and Fallout: New Vegas , Fallout 76 should strongly consider breaking this promise, now more than ever.

Fallout 76 Could Be the ‘New Vegas 2’ That Never Happened

With Fallout 76 ’s Vertibird Expeditions, the journey from Appalachia to the New Vegas Strip would be conveniently possible for the big update coming to Fallout 76 in December 2025, which was recently teased at the Summer Games Fest showcase to visit Fallout: New Vegas ’ Wasteland. Given each game’s placement in the timeline, it would have to be an earlier version of the New Vegas Wasteland, but Fallout 76 could still pay respects to Fallout: New Vegas with this upcoming update.

If I had the chance, I’d no-life a Fallout: New Vegas remaster in a heartbeat. Unfortunately, while it seems like a proper sequel or remaster isn’t happening soon, the Fallout show and Fallout 76 arguably have the perfect opportunity to give Fallout: New Vegas the respect that it’s due with both a spiritual prequel and sequel, nonetheless. And since the Fallout show’s season two has already confirmed a visit to the New Vegas Wasteland, Fallout 76 should arguably follow suit, giving me and other Fallout: New Vegas fans the perfect Christmas gift, also using this opportunity to be more closely involved with the award-winning show.

item.title: Monopoly GO: Free Dice Roll Links (Updated Daily)
item.description:
Monopoly GO is a fun board game that combines the classic Monopoly experience with cool additional features and a city-building element. In the game, players can move their pieces to earn money and then use that money to build new buildings, upgrade their houses, and much more. The ultimate goal is to drive other players into bankruptcy by acquiring all pieces of property, essentially creating a “monopoly.”

In Monopoly GO , players move according to the numbers of dice they get, and the game proceeds with renting, trading, and buying properties. If players have finished their dice rolls and want to get some more, here’s how they can do it.

Updated by Umama Ali on June 17, 2025: Without dice, you can’t roll around the board, build landmarks, or participate in any tournaments. Running out of dice can slow down your progress in Monopoly GO, leaving you at a disadvantage compared to other players. With the release of Hyperspace Partners, fans are looking for more dice rolls. We’ve updated this guide with a bunch of new links that offer free dice rolls so that you can keep building in Monopoly GO. Check back regularly to find new Monopoly GO dice links.

We discovered two new dice links on June 17. You can find all the active Monopoly GO dice links in the table below.

Free Monopoly GO Dice Links For Today

While your dice rolls slowly replenish over time, you can use Dice Links to get free dice rolls instantly. Dice Links are a quick and easy way to grab free dice and keep the action going in Monopoly GO . Here are all the active Monopoly GO dice links for June 2025 to help you participate in ongoing events and tournaments and complete boards easily.
Monopoly GO Dice Links Date
25 x Dice Rolls Jun 15 - Jun 18
25 x Dice Rolls Jun 16 - Jun 19
25 x Dice Rolls Jun 16 - Jun 19
25 x Dice Rolls Jun 14 - Jun 17
25 x Dice Rolls Jun 13 - Jun 16
25 x Dice Rolls Jun 12 - Jun 15
30 x Dice Rolls Jun 13 - Jun 20
25 x Dice Rolls Jun 12 - Jun 16
30 x Dice Rolls Jun 08 - Jun 15

Expired Monopoly GO Dice Links

  • 25 x Dice Rolls
  • 25 x Dice Rolls

  • 25 x Dice Rolls

  • 25 x Dice Rolls
  • 25 x Dice Rolls

How to Redeem Dice Links in Monopoly GO

To redeem these links, tycoons can follow these simple steps:
  • Open a link on your phone. This will launch the Monopoly GO app on your device.
  • All you need to do then is click 'Collect,' and you'll get dice rolls for free.

How To Get Free Dice Rolls In Monopoly Go

Login Daily

Like most mobile games nowadays, Monopoly GO also offers incentives for players so that they frequently play the game. One of the daily treats is free dice rolls, so logging in daily is one way to get them. In addition to dice rolls, players have the chance to win other exciting prizes as well.

Invite Friends

Monopoly GO offers generous rewards for players who successfully invite others to join the game. If a player invites a friend, and the invited friend joins the game, both of them get 30 extra rolls . Players can keep getting 30 free rolls for inviting up to 30 friends , given that they accept the invitation.

Collect Community Chest Rewards

Community chests are great because they offer a variety of rewards. Players can open these chests to earn money, and if they help a friend with a community chest, they can earn some free rolls.
To make the most out of the community chest, players must ensure that they have at least 9 active in-game friends.

Complete Sticker Albums

Players collect stickers throughout Monopoly GO , and they aren’t just a fun part of the game; they can help players get dice rolls , too. For every sticker set or album that players complete, they receive dice rolls. While the free rolls earned through sticker albums are more than those obtained after completing a set, the process of completing an album can be more time-consuming.
small
Related

Monopoly GO: How to Play and Win the Partner Event

Partner Event is a popular social event in Monopoly GO that allows tycoons to team up with their friends. Here’s everything you need to know about it.

Participate in Events and Tournaments

If you want a bunch of dice rolls, consider participating in events and tournaments. The game introduces new events regularly, and by completing their milestones, you can claim dice rolls, different sticker packs, in-game money, and various other exciting prizes . Tournaments also pack a lot of stellar rewards, so players should aim to secure a high position on the tournament leaderboard to make the most of them.

Special Events

Apart from the main events and tournaments, Monopoly GO also has a number of special events. From Free Parking to Wheel Boost, the game offers many events to help you grab some dice rolls. However, their timings change every day, so you can check out our daily events schedule guide to know when they happen.
